In the end last night was one of wild celebration in the Toon as goals from two home debutants and a forgotten man beat a stubborn Derby side. Not even the dismissal of Warren Barton for hauling back Deon Burton or Seth Johnson's late second could spoil the party.

Summer building work has increased the capacity to more than 52,000 and Tyneside hosted its largest crowd since 1973 with the darling of the Gallowgate that day, Malcolm Macdonald, back to mark the occasion. It was clear they expected Derby, without six regulars, to be torn apart - Rams to the slaughter.

The breathtaking start suggested as much. With four minutes gone Kieron Dyer fed Nolberto Solano down the right. The Peruvian tricked his way past Danny Higginbotham and crossed for Carl Cort who, under challenge from Otto Bragstad, headed into the corner of the net.

But, while the Newcastle whirlwind continued to rage, it rapidly blew out of control. Burton might have levelled had Nicos Dabizas not intevened and, when United did emerge from midfield with the ball, Solano's pass was just too strong for the on-rushing Dyer.

Rhythm was further disrupted by Cort's withdrawal after the half-hour as County's midfield steadily took control. Stefano Eranio teased his way past two players before curling an effort over the bar and Burton should have done better moments later when through on goal.

The crowd, starved of their goal feast, vented their frustrations. Their disappointment was complete on the stroke of half-time as Johnson's innocuous ball into the area caught the home defence dithering and Branko Strupar calmly placed an equaliser beyond Shay Given.

But parity was retained only for the duration of the interval. A minute after the break Stephen Glass's cross was half-cleared by the beleaguered Bragstad and Cordone nipped in to restore United's lead.

This time there would be no revival. Glass, who spent most of last season on the treatment table or the transfer list and was seizing his chance with some glee, saw to that by curling a magnificent left-foot shot into the top corner from 30 yards.

Higginbotham's last ditch challenge prevented Alan Shearer adding a fourth but Derby's defence had long since descended into blind panic. Macdonald must have fancied his chances.

Modern English batsmanship, by and large, attracts the sort of notices associated with uncompromising socialists and any movie starring Jean-Claude van Damme. All the more reason, therefore, to have been here yesterday. David Graveney was, although whether what he witnessed provoked delight or dismay is another kettle of cod entirely.

On a sluggish pitch whose occasionally subterranean bounce is expected to make batting last a fraught affair, Mike Atherton, John Crawley and Andrew Flintoff put Lancashire in sight of a significant lead in their vividly contrasting ways. Crawley alone turned control into a century but the spectacle was no less hypnotic for that.

Obliged, seemingly, to accommodate a spinner at the Oval - how Laker, Lock and Wardle would have reacted to such a state of affairs one shudders to think - the England selectors could always go on form and do the brave thing: drop Atherton.

Troubled initially by Jon Dakin's pace, he never got out of second gear yet pushed, steered and nudged his way to 48 in 51 overs before being trapped by Phil DeFreitas's grubber. For England to take on Courtney and Curtly without the master of stubbornness still seems too risky.

Outscoring Atherton four-to-one in a 97-run partnership, Crawley all but toyed with Anil Kumble, endorsing the conviction held by some that overlooking his expertise against spin on the subcontinent would be even riskier.

His partnership with Flintoff, who biffed 55 off 60 balls, added 89 at nearly seven an over and was akin to being confronted with a set meal offering the best of Thai and British. Where Crawley is all subtle spices and light noodles, Flintoff is strictly meat and potatoes; Kumble undid him, as he always appeared destined to.

To see the Indian sans moustache - the result of a vow at Canterbury that resulted in his most productive match of a so-so summer - is shocking enough. Now he has promised, should he make a century, to grow a beard of Sherwood Forest proportions, so the abrupt end to his sturdy knock, bowled by Glen Chapple, was bad news for those despairing of the current rash of slapheads and hankering after the new WG.

After the way Kumble bowled, mind, that upper lip may soon be restored to its familiar shrubbery. Playing into Crawley's deft hands, he strayed all too frequently to leg and waited 19 overs for his sole wicket. Perhaps this novel attempt to reverse the Samson principle is wearing off.

Amid it all buzzed the Chris Lewis grapevine. The former England all-rounder is said to be so fed up with what he sees as the reluctance of officialdom to take his allegations of bookmaker approaches seriously that he is threatening to retire in order to "write" a book naming the England players he was asked to approach by a bookmaker.

Not that Leicestershire would be distraught. Given that a hip ailment has restricted him to fewer than 100 championship overs, Lewis has been about as useful as Banquo's ghost, and only marginally more visible. Patience is thinning.

"It'll all come out in the wash," said Leicestershire's coach Jack Birkenshaw, somewhat obliquely. One can only guess whether Lewis is seeking revenge for a perceived slight, trying to earn a few bob for his dotage or has genuine cause to shatter English cricket's holier-than-thou self-image.

A Russian woman who was forcibly sedated after she shrieked abuse at a senior minister has become a potent symbol of Moscow's continuing intolerance of dissent.

Images of the incident have been broadcast and published throughout the world. They show the young blonde woman - the mother of one of the sailors who died horribly in the Kursk submarine - screaming her angry comments at Ilya Klebanov, the deputy prime minister in charge of investigating the disaster. An officer tries, without success, to calm the woman, before a nurse slides into the picture, clearly holding a hypodermic syringe. Moments later, the blond woman slumps to the ground, before being helped to a chair.

Officials later suggested that the woman's sedation was motivated by compassion. That explanation is as crass as the sedation itself, which took place in full view of a local television crew. At least in Russia today the authorities cannot muzzle the media, though they can silence a protesting mother.

In the Soviet era these things were organised better. The woman have been dealt with more swiftly and effectively, and the images would never have got out. In our own enlightened times, what happened was less sinister than bovinely stupid. And yet the incident raises all kinds of disturbing, fascinating questions about censorship and manipulation; about dissent and dissimulation.

There is a western tendency to smugness when it comes to media freedom. We congratulate ourselves for being able to call Bill Clinton a fornicating liar or Tony Blair a grinning prat. That kind of freedom is indeed precious, but it is superficial. So far as the mainstream media are concerned, there are many sly and pernicious restraints on freedom, most clearly explained by the US intellectual giant Noam Chomsky. If we accept that our freedom is not total, we may understand better what happens elsewhere. For free expression is a highly subjective matter, and what we regard as a precious right may in some countries be seen as an intolerable abuse.

India, for example, is a vigorous democracy. Its press is far from reverent, let alone obsequious. But on issues perceived to be of national importance, the Indian media tends instinctively to close ranks behind the government of the day. Kashmir is an obvious example: there can be strident criticism of day-to-day handling of the situation, but it is unthinkable that the mainstream media would question, let alone oppose, the notion that Kashmir is an indivisible part of India.

Another interesting dichotomy is between the private sector press and the state controlled television service, Doordarshan. The broadcasters in theory enjoy the same freedoms as their print colleagues, but in practice their news bulletins are dreary recitals of what the prime minister has said and done that day. The same is true, with knobs on, in next-door Pakistan, where at least the broadcasters have the current excuse of labouring under a military junta. But it was just the same in the days of Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, both of whom insisted that the Pakistan Television news be little more than a court circular.

This confusion of the state with its rulers is ubiquitous in the Third World, as the Channel 4 news team now in custody in Liberia has found to its cost. They were doing what they ought to do: asking awkward, probing questions. But when they started to gather material that might have been embarrassing for Liberia's strongman leader Charles Taylor, they tripped the wire that binds together Nation, Ruler and Authority. We might scoff when Liberian ministers talk of Channel 4's "espionage" but to a certain mindset that's exactly what their activity amounted to.

In Russia and the former Eastern Bloc, elements of the same confusion exist more than a decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall. It was always naive to suppose that Western media standards could be transplanted wholesale into Eastern Europe - even if that was desirable. The region is still in a transitional stage, in which even impeccable liberals like the Czech Republic's Vaclav Havel have an instinctive distrust of 'free' television.

Indeed, rulers of every democratic hue, and of course despots of all kinds, are mesmerised by television. Its raw power to inform and to delude is undoubted, but in its conventional form it is the medium which, next to newspapers, those rulers can most easily control and manipulate. Oddly, the same rulers and manipulators have, for two generations at least, overlooked the much greater threat/opportunity of radio to subvert/inform. John Tusa, the former BBC World Service chief, strongly believes that it was radio, more than any other medium, which brought down the Wall.

Now the internet is the new radio, along with satellite television and, to an extent, mobile telephony. The new media are no respecters of frontiers, or even of laws. They allow the most extravagant conspiracy theories to flourish and, of course, they can be used to explain in graphic detail how the mainstream media have been suborned by big business.

Impressive phrases such as"the geopolitics of information" are woven into earnest academic treatises on the internet's impact on politics, on the Third World and, for that matter, more or less any other aspect of life.

The plain fact is that the net is more effective than any other medium for spreading news, views and images around the globe, with or without the permission of the kind of people who believe that distraught mothers should be sedated rather than give offence to a minister.

The return to prison of Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair may have been welcomed by law-abiding citizens in Northern Ireland, but he was the last person the prison officers at Maghaberry jail wanted to see.

Loyalist paramilitaries have threatened action against prison officers and their families unless segregation is introduced at the County Antrim jail.

The prison operates a policy of integration, with loyalist and republican prisoners living side by side with other inmates.

Sources with an intimate knowledge of Maghaberry said yesterday that staff feared he would become a rallying point for the loyalist prisoners, who are demanding the same rights as they were given inside the Maze.

Following the suspension of his licence for early release, Adair was dragged from his car on the Shankill road on Monday night by officers from the RUC's SAS-trained headquarters mobile support unit.

He was driven to Girdwood Barracks in Belfast, and flown to Maghaberry in a helicopter.

Once hailed as a model prison, Maghaberry has become a powder keg since the Good Friday agreement was signed. It was built to house "good honest criminals" not associated with terrorism, but members of paramilitary groups convicted or charged after the agreement have been sent there instead of the Maze, due to close in the autumn.

About 120 of the jail's 493 prisoners are affiliated to the Ulster Freedom Fighters and Loyalist Volunteer Force, a breakaway group set up by the infamous Portadown loyalist Billy Wright, who was shot dead in the Maze prison by the INLA two days after Christmas in 1997.

It was a spokesman for the LVF prisoners, who do not qualify for early release as the terrorist organisation has not declared a ceasefire, who issued the threat against the prison staff and their families.

Since Adair was freed from the Maze last September after serving five years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism, he has tried to forge close links with the LVF to muscle in on the lucrative drugs trade in Portadown.

Adair has publicly aligned himself with the LVF prisoners' demands, and prison sources fear a worsening of the violence that has already seen more than 60 officers injured in Maghaberry this year and several petrol bomb attacks on their homes.

But the prison authorities are adamant that they will not introduce the policies that resulted in the Maze being run by inmates.

The Maze was a home from home for Adair, who even had a mobile phone to direct operations on the streets of Belfast.

Maghaberry remains a much stricter regime than the H blocks. Yesterday the Northern Ireland prison service stressed that mobile phones were not tolerated in the jail and that Adair would be afforded no special privileges.

As well as breaking the hearts of Camelot executives, yesterday's lottery announcement shattered two golden rules. First, nothing of political significance happens in August. Second, every government announcement is always briefed well in advance. New Labour's in-house newspaper, the Mirror, confidently reported yesterday that "Camelot is today set to win the race to run the National Lottery again".

And these were not the only unique aspects of the announcements. While Chris Smith only knew about the decision earlier this week, No 10 advisers apparently found out at the same time as the rest of us.

Underlining the independence from political interference of the national lottery commission - and its improbably named chair Dame Helena Shovelton - is important for the government. Especially given that the decision to go with Branson is without question good news for New Labour. One of the most effective stories in Labour's 1997 election campaign was around the pledge to create a "People's Lottery". This pledge took up a whole section of Labour's manifesto. The measures in the 1998 Lottery Act committing distributors to focus more on social and regional need meant that the government was able to demonstrate it had met many of its promises. But the problem lay in the last line of the manifesto commitment: "Labour will seek an efficient not-for-profit operator to ensure that the maximum sums go to good causes." The Branson bid, as well as shrewdly taking the title "People's Lottery" from Labour, fulfils this last pledge.

So far so good. But while the success of the Branson bid is a result for the government, it doesn't end the controversy surrounding this national institution. While the likely establishment of the People's Lottery will be a useful addition to Labour's achievement list at next year's general election there are plenty of things that could go wrong in time to be an embarrassment in a Blair second term.

For a start the new organisers of the lottery will be taking over a business in decline. Recently, lottery sales have been declining or stagnant. Branson may not take the £230m in profits reaped by Camelot but this figure represents only 1.5% of the money for good causes pledged by both Virgin and Camelot. A decline in lottery sales of less than 1% would more than offset the benefits of not retaining profits. So the People's Lottery will need to succeed and be seen to succeed.

The second set of challenges concern legitimacy. Being not-for-profit helps but it doesn't solve as many problems as might appear. As trade union activists will tell you in the light of some general secretaries' salaries and perks, you don't have to be a capitalist to be a fat cat. The People's Lottery will still need senior executive and they will still be paid out of the proceeds. More fundamentally, the lottery will continue to be played disproportional by the poor. As the Right Rev Richard Harries, Bishop of Oxford, reminded us this week, many people maintain that the lottery is economically unfair, encourages gambling and fosters disempowering fantasies of escape amongst those at the bottom of the heap.

But the main question of legitimacy will continue to be the way the money is spent. Camelot executives never tired of telling us that they had no control over this. Of course, they were right. The responsibility for the distribution of the money lies in the hands of culture secretary Chris Smith and is devolved by him to various bodies ranging from the arts councils to the millennium commission and the new opportunities fund. It is with these bodies that the responsibility for controversial decisions like the purchase of the Churchill papers or the huge grant to the Royal Opera House. But awards of this kind do undermine the overall popularity of the lottery as an (albeit highly inefficient) form of charitable giving.

In relation to distribution, the funding bodies are stuck between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand many on the left continue to defend the often breached pledge that the lottery should not be used for funding mainstream public services. On the other hand many on the right go into apoplexy when lottery money is given to "politically correct" charities like those giving advice to gays. This inevitable controversy points to why the decision to go with Branson could ultimately prove to be a double-edged sword. While Camelot has been only too willing to fall into line with government wishes in a desperate attempt to salvage its battered credibility, Branson continues to be one of the most popular people in Britain. If Sir Richard feels the administration of lottery money is damaging its success he will say so loud and clear and - given his highly polished PR skills - with popular support. After all, anyone who can remain popular and respected while running the west coast main line must be made of Teflon. If Branson takes on the government over the lottery the sparks will certainly fly. I can even predict the sound-bite when the first argument kicks off: "this is not the New Labour lottery it is the People's Lottery".

New security procedures may soon make it safer to use your Visa card or MasterCard online than in person. From next April, all Visa card and MasterCard holders in the UK will have to give out a three-digit security number printed on the card signature strip during online and telephone based transactions. As an additional means of identification, they will also have to give their house name or number and postcode .

The security number is calculated from your card's 16-digit number and other numeric data unique to your account. In theory, only cash machines, electronic point of sale machines and your card issuer's computer systems can confirm this number.

Credit card fraud in the UK cost a staggering £189m last year, and is rising.

Stolen till rolls or restaurant receipts are all that is needed for someone to take your card number and expiry date and then use your details for buying goods over the telephone or online. Alternatively, your card details can easily, and quickly, be copied by a less than scrupulous shop assistant using a simple magnetic strip reader costing around £50. These gizmos, when hooked up to a laptop computer - which could easily be under the checkout - can record all of the existing data on your card. But they will not be able to record the new security number as it is printed on your signature strip.

Thanks to the new security number, known as the card verification value, and the extra identification checks, Visa and MasterCard say it will be easier for online merchants and telephone mail-order houses to spot fraudulent card activity.

Some UK online retailers, most notably Quip (www.quip.co.uk), the discount telecoms company, have already implemented the card verfication value and house number safeguards, so if you do find these details requested when you make a transaction over the phone or online, rest assured that it's for your own protection. If, on the other hand, you see a shop assistant or waiter noting down the card verfication value or other data from the signature strip of your card, alarm bells should start ringing in your head. Don't be afraid of asking for an explanation and if necessary calling for the manager.

The "consumer tips" section on Visa's main website (which is at www.visa.com/ct) has a useful selection of dos and don'ts for when using your card at a retailer, online or at a cash machine.

Many recommendations are commonsense, but some are less than obvious, such as cancelling a cash machine transaction at any stage if you see anything suspicious about the machine, a simple procedure that can save a lot of hassle.

Visa also recommends that you don't let your card out of your sight in a shop or a restaurant. Although this can involve a trip to the till from your table, the minor inconvenience could save a lot of grief further down the line.

Not all problematic transactions are fraudulent. Suppose you order a product online and nothing arrives at all. Or, perhaps, the product arrives, but your bill is for more than you agreed. Unravelling these messes takes time and effort, not to mention a lot of brain strain.

Now a new web-based service aims to solve these problems by providing a service which allows you to prove to your card issuer - and to the online retailer - what really happened. The Card-Guard (www.card-guard.com) service allows all types of e-commerce transactions, including Switch and Visa Delta, to be securely recorded on a your PC for later playback.

The Card-Guard software sits in the background on your PC, recording any transactions you make. Copies of these transactions are then encrypted and saved to your hard disk.

If a dispute occurs, you simply send a copy of the encrypted transaction to Card-Guard. The firm then allows you secure access to the decrypted copy. Basically, if something goes wrong with a transaction you can prove your side of the story.

The service is free to use except when users retrieve their encrypted transaction records from the company's servers, for which it charges a modest fee.

There are currently two ways of paying for this service: a pay-as-you-go model at £5.50 per retrieved transaction or an annual subscription model for prepaid transaction retrievals.

The first charging model allows users to test the service and, if nothing goes wrong with any of your online transactions, you won't have to pay a penny.

Under the subscription model, users can pay either £17.50 or £35 a year for, respectively, 10 or 20 free transaction retrievals in that given year.

Plans are also in the pipeline for the company to develop an approved retailers programme on its site. Under the programmme, users will be assured of a basic level of service from such approved retailers. Users will get confirmation of their orders by e-mail and several other guaranteed services. These are basic features which many e-commerce sites ignore at their peril.

Card safety

 Ensure that you get your credit card back after every purchase. If possible, do not let it out of your sight.

 Never give your card number over the phone, unless you are dealing with a reputable company or you have initiated the call yourself.

 If you feel pressured by a tele-marketing salesperson, be suspicious and never give out your account number unless you've decided to make a purchase.

 Do not volunteer any personal information when you use your card.

 After completing an ATM or Debit transaction, remember to take your card and, if provided, your transaction record

Make sure that anyone waiting to use a cash machine after you cannot see you entering your PIN or transaction amount.

 Never write down your PIN - memorise it. And never disclose it to anyone. No one from a financial institution or the police should ask for it. Nor should a retailer. You are the only person who should know it.

 When selecting a PIN, avoid the obvious such as your name, telephone number, or date of birth.

 If your card becomes stuck inside a cash machine, be suspicious of anyone offering help, even if they appear to be a bank security officer. Criminals can obtain your PIN by several means (shoulder surfing or straight questioning), then retrieve your card from the machine and use it to withdraw funds.

 Do not leave your receipt behind - take it with you. Compare your cash machine receipts to your monthly statement.

All the advice above was taken from the Visa website at: www.visa.com.

Six people were being questioned today after a 21-year-old man was shot dead in Belfast - the latest victim of the worsening feud between loyalist terror groups.

Sam Rocket was visiting his girlfriend and one-year-old daughter in the Old Park area of the city when he was attacked by an unknown number of gunmen.

Rocket is thought to have been a friend of the son of Billy Hutchinson of the Progressive Unionist party, the political arm of the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF). The attack is thought to have been carried out by the Ulster Defence Association (UDA) as revenge for the murder of two men on Monday.

Hardline loyalists warned today that they expected the feud to continue. "There are those on both sides hellbent on continuing it until they feel they have drawn enough blood," said Mr Hutchinson.

The UDA and UVF are both supposed to be observing a joint ceasefire in support of the Good Friday Peace agreement.

The Rocket family had been linked to the UDA, but were expelled in the mid-1990s. Some family members had since realigned themselves with the UVF.

Police arrested six more people last night after a chase on Belfast's Shankill Road. A submachine gun, a rifle, a shotgun and three handguns were found abandoned on the pavement.

John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic party, warned that Rocket would not be the last to die. "This is something I was expecting. And I don't see an end to it," he said. "I'm not condemning it," said Mr White, convicted of a double murder in 1972.

Former Chinese slave labourers have launched a test case in the US against two leading Japanese companies, claiming that they were submitted to inhuman treatment during the second world war.

The claim, filed yesterday against the Mitsubishi and Mitsui groups in a Los Angeles court, revives memories of Japan's extensive use of Chinese and Korean forced labour.

Harsh conditions and lack of food in virtual prison camps resulted in perhaps hundreds of thousands of deaths, in their countries and in Japan.

The case has been launched by four Chinese-Americans now living in California, and five residents of Beijing. The US lawyer Barry Fisher said yesterday that "this is a suit on behalf of Chinese people victimised during the war. There were millions."

Last year, California passed a law allowing former prisoners of war exploited as slave labourers to file claims until 2010. Most of the Chinese and Korean slave labourers were civilians, but they were abducted by the Japanese army.

Workers from north China were mobilised in the 1930s to serve in Manchuria, north-eastern China, which was already under Japanese domination. In 1941, a plan was set up to draft 1.1m more "special workers" for Manchuria. Three years later, Tokyo began transporting Chinese workers.

A 1997 report by Japanese labour researchers to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), says that the imperial army was put in charge of a massive hunt for Chinese workers. By the war's end, more than 10% of Japan's coal output was dug by Chinese labour.

Out of nearly 39,000 Chinese workers brought to Japan, 17.5% are said to have died - many of them within three months of arrival.

 IG Farben, the German chemical company that made gas for death camps, will set up a compensation fund, starting at £155,000, for Nazi-era slave labourers. The firm, dissolved by the allies in 1952, remains as a trust to settle lawsuits from the Nazi era.

Divers have retrieved the two "black box" recorders from the Gulf Air Airbus A320 which crashed into the sea last night, killing all 143 people on board, an airline official said today.

The rescue teams, which included US Navy helicopters and destroyers, managed to reach the wreckage of the plane - lying in shallow waters a few miles off the northern coast of Bahrain - within hours, but there were no survivors.

Two Britons and 36 children are among those who died on board GF072, an evening flight from Cairo to Manama. Relatives spent the morning identifying victims of the crash from photos taken after all the bodies were recovered.

There was no immediate word on what caused the crash. Ali Ahmadi, a Gulf Air vice president, said investigations have begun, but Bahraini officials will wait for experts from France's Airbus Industrie and the US-based national transportation safety board for a more thorough probe.

The aircraft, which Gulf Air said was carrying 135 passengers and eight crew, crashed north of Bahrain airport at about 5.30pm yesterday.

Most of the passengers were Arab nationals - including 63 Egyptians, 34 Bahrainis, 12 Saudi Arabians, nine Palestinians, six United Arab Emirates nationals, a Kuwaiti and an Omani. There were also two Britons, an Australian, a Canadian, three Chinese people, one Sudanese national and a Korean. There were also unconfirmed reports that one of the passengers was a US diplomatic courier.

It is not yet known why flight GF072 crashed but an air traffic controller at Bahrain airport described watching from the tower as the plane circled the runway twice in an attempt to land, then on the third attempt plunged into the sea and exploded into flames.

The controller, who asked to remain anonymous, saw no sign of trouble before the crash and said the plane's crew had not reported anything out of the ordinary.

However, the ministry of transportation in Bahrain released a statement saying reports of an engine fire was "pure speculation".

The statement said: "It appeared that the aircraft had made two previous attempts to land and as it was turning to make another approach, it veered into the sea.

"Contrary to some initial reports, suggestions that an engine was on fire is pure speculation. The Air Traffic Control recordings confirm the crew made no distress call."

US navy helicopters based in Bahrain, the home of the US fifth fleet, joined the rescue operation last night, according to a Pentagon spokesman, Bryan Whitman. The Catawba, a US navy support ship with a dive team, is also being dispatched to the scene. About 100 US military personnel were sent to help from the USS George Washington - which usually patrols the Gulf but was in port - at the request of the Bahraini government, said Lieutenant John Perkins, a navy spokesman.

A Foreign Office spokesman could not confirm last night whether Britons were on board. Gulf Air urged worried relatives to call the information line on 0845 604 0171.

Bahrain's ruler, Sheikh Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa, said last night that he had ordered an investigation into the crash. He also announced a three-day mourning period for the crash victims.

Paul Beaver, a Jane's defence specialist, said: "Gulf Air has been going for 40 years and has an excellent safety record. There have been a few bumps and scratches but nothing as catastrophic as losing a plane."

Gulf Air was arranging for a special flight from Cairo to Bahrain later today to take families of the deceased to the crash site and similar arrangements were being made for other families.

Gulf Air's most recent disaster came in 1983, when a 737-200 crashed during approach to Abu Dhabi after a bomb exploded in the baggage compartment. The crash killed all six crew members and 105 of 111 passengers.

Former MI5 officer David Shayler was today formally charged in court with breaking the Official Secrets Act and bailed.

He was bailed on the condition that he lived with his brother Philip in Wimbledon, south-west London, and was also given permission to stay with a friend on Teesside so he could watch Saturday's match against Leeds United at the Riverside Stadium.

Mr Shayler appeared calm and relaxed as he stood in the dock of court one at Bow Street magistrates court, central London.

Outside the court he said he was "very glad" the legal process had got under way, adding: "I'm very glad that the magistrate was sympathetic enough to me to let go and see Middlesbrough."

He faces two charges of breaking section one of the 1989 Official Secrets Act, over an article in the Mail on Sunday in which he made allegations about his former employer, MI5.

In the article, he claimed that security chiefs had kept files on prominent Labour politicians, including Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson, Home Secretary Jack Straw - who was described as a "communist sympathiser" - and had also kept files on former Beatle John Lennon and punk band the Sex Pistols. The formal charge read: "On or before the 24th day of August 1997 within the jurisdiction of the Central Criminal Court being a person who has been a member of the security and intelligence services without lawful authority disclosed documents relating to security or intelligence which were in your possession by virtue of your position."

Mr Shayler's solicitor John Wadham, of the civil rights group Liberty, told the magistrate that the 34-year-old former agent would be pleading not guilty at a later hearing.

Mr Shayler claims that his allegations were made in the public interest and did not damage national security. New European human rights legislation, that will become part of English law in October, may provide him with a defence against the charges.

Mr Shayler, 34, was arrested by Special Branch officers at Dover on Monday after returning from three years self-imposed "political exile" in France, and immediately taken to Charing Cross police station where he was charged and released on bail.

The charges do not include the more serious allegations Mr Shayler went on to make in the media, including claims that MI6 was behind a bungled plot to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gaddafi that left several civilians dead.

Marcello Lippi, the man who Alex Ferguson rates as the "best coach in Europe," is facing the sack today after his Internazionale side crashed out of the Champions League to Swedish part-timers Helsingborg.

Despite losing the first leg 1-0, Inter went into the return match at the San Siro last night expecting a comfortable victory. But although they ripped through the Swedes' defensive line time and time again, they found Helsingborg's 36-year-old keeper Sven Andersson in sensational form.

He was called into action as early as the 10th minute, straining to reach a Zamorano header that crept just wide. And the barrage continued as twice in the space of two minutes Pirlo wriggled free of his markers to set up first Zamorano and then himself with good shooting opportunities.

At the start of the second half, Pirlo and Zamorano were replaced by Recoba and Keane, but Inter's onslaught continued. Keane hit the post with a back-heel in the 52nd minute and then was brilliantly denied 10 minutes later by Andersson after he followed up a fierce Jugovic shot.

As the game entered injury time, Inter looked dead and buried. But then, suddenly, they were awarded a penalty. The 50,000 in the San Siro went wild: they were back in it. Recoba stepped to take it and fired the ball low and hard to Andersson's right.

But the Swedish keeper - once again - was equal to it. Lowly Helsingborg had knocked out one of the biggest names in European football from the Champions League, and they couldn't quite believe it.

"The last 15 minutes we were on our knees," admitted Andersson. "It was bloody warm down there on the pitch. When the referee awarded the penalty, I thought that was it. We had been fighting for 90 minutes and we get a bloody penalty against us."

"I thought that I had to save the penalty. It would have been awful if we had lost this tie in the final minute after fighting so hard for 180 minutes. We were so tired we would never got through any extra time."

Helsingborg manager Nanne Bergstrand - who has come under criticism after a poor spell of results - sounded like a vindicated man. "This is the greatest thing that has happened in the history of the club," he said. "I'm astonished about the way we had energy to work hard through the entire game. It's amazing considering we've been playing three games a week for the last seven weeks."

His opposite number Lippi, by contrast, looked defeated and disconsolate. "Our dreams are broken," he admitted. "We are out and we have lost to a team who we know we are better than."

But later he tried to sound upbeat: "We have to put that behind us and go on," he claimed. "As for my situation, you have to talk with the president and with the club executives. I cannot answer for them."

But if the fans that stoned the Inter bus have anything to say then Lippi will be out of a job. The only consolation he has is that there's no obvious replacement waiting in the wings - but given club president Massimo Moratti's habit of sacking managers, even that might not save him.

The A320 was the state of the art in airliner design when it entered service in April 1988 as the world's first fully computerised civil aircraft.

The 150-seat short- to medium-haul aircraft was the first commercial airliner to employ fly-by-wire technology using a computer to optimise the plane's performance.

The computer control prevents the plane from going too fast or making dangerous manoeuvres as well as ensuring efficient use of fuel.

The A320, with a range of 3,000 nautical miles, boasts 840 planes in service with 82 operators worldwide.

By the end of March 2000, the fleet had accumulated over 10.5m flight hours in over 6.1m departures.

It is the fastest-selling commercial aircraft in the world alongside the Boeing 737.

David Learmount, operations and safety editor of Flight International magazine said: "There were three fatal accidents in the first three years of the A320's life which had more to do with crews getting used to the new control systems than anything else."

In one accident, 87 people were killed near Strasbourg, in eastern France, when the aircraft flew into a mountain.

Mr Learmount said: "It was not because the control system went wrong, but because the pilots were not used to it."

Previous accidents

1988 An A320 crashed at the Mulhouse-Habsheim air show in eastern France, killing four people.

1990 Ninety-two people died when an Indian airlines A320 crashed near Bangalore airport in February 1990.

1992 87 killed when A320 crashed in Strasbourg

1995 The pilot of an Excalibur Airways A320 jet carrying 185 holidaymakers and seven crew could not turn left because British Airways engineers failed to reconnect controls after maintenance. The plane made a high-speed crash landing at Gatwick.

1998 Three killed when A320 crashed on landing in the Philippines.

1998 A Monarch Airlines A320 made two emergency landings at Luton airport on its way to Verona, Italy, from Manchester. None of the 156 passengers and seven crew were injured.

1998 A Spanish-bound Airtours A320 carrying 149 passengers from Gatwick had to divert to Stansted after engine panels fell off.

The bitter feud between rival loyalist factions in Belfast is threatening to escalate further after another man was shot dead last night.

The shooting came 27 hours after the re-arrest of Ulster Freedom Fighter boss Johnny Adair, who vowed to fight the decision to send him back to jail.

The victim, 21-year-old Sam Rocket, was gunned down last night just a few hundred yards from the scene of a double murder by the UVF on Monday.

Bobby Mahood, a close associate of Adair, and fellow militant Jackie Coulter, were shot in Belfast's Crumin Road. Mr Mahood will be buried today.

Mr Rocket was was shot as he sat in the living room of his girlfriend's home in Summer Street, off Cliftonpark Avenue on the north of the city, and died in hospital a short time later. His young daughter was also believed to have been in the room at the time of the attack. His family were reportedly expelled from the Ulster Defence Association - aligned to the UFF - in the mid-1990s and had switched allegiance to the rival Ulster Volunteer Force. The finger is already being pointed at the UFF, who blamed the UVF for the murders of Mr Mahood and Mr Coulter.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson condemned last night's murder as a "cowardly act bringing the loyalist feud to new depths".

Mr Mandelson yesterday stood by his decision to send "Mad Dog" Adair back to prison.

The UFF leader is planning legal action to overturn the decision and met his legal team at Co Antrim's Maghaberry prison to make preparations for a possible high court judicial review.

Mr Mandelson promised to fight any court action. He said: "I will maintain my decision in whatever forum I have to. I am entirely confident I was right.

"There is always a risk that maverick individuals will want to pursue this blood feud and we must be on our guard. But over time I believe the removal of Mr Adair will cause tension to subside.

"The Shankill community leaders I have been speaking to have said things are calm on the ground. There is no sense of any backlash."

He insisted recent violence did not mean the loyalist ceasefires had been broken, because he argued, an individual's wrongdoing was not necessarily directed by an organisation.

"By no means do all the UDA or UFF support or subscribe to the actions of Johnny Adair," he said.

Police yesterday questioned a man in connection with the double murder but released him without charge.

John White, of the Ulster Democratic Party, the UFF's political wing, said: "I have been trying to encourage people to start talking again. I have been told in no uncertain terms there will be no talking. The UFF want to extract their retribution."

Progressive Unionist Billy Hutchinson, whose party represents the rival Ulster Volunteer Force, said: "I think both organisations need to take a step back and look at where they are going but I would be concerned there will be more attacks.

"I understand that people will want revenge but there will have to be mediation eventually between the two organisations.

The sentence review commission will now examine Mr Mandelson's decision, taking written submissions from both the secretary of state and Adair's legal team. It will give a preliminary finding which either side can challenge at an oral hearing, which could lead to a high court judicial review if it is contested. If Adair loses, his earliest release date will be May 2002.

Four members of a Channel 4 television crew held on spying charges in the West African state of Liberia were yesterday denied bail by a judge in the capital, Monrovia.

Judge Timothy Swope's ruling in the criminal court came as defence lawyers claimed the men - two Britons, a Sierra Leonean and a South African - had been threatened with torture and abused after being held overnight in the national security agency's compound.

Britons David Barrie and Zimbabwean-born Timothy Lambon, South African Gugulakhe Radebe and Sierra Leonean Sorious Samura were later seen by a US embassy doctor and reported to be in a satisfactory condition.

"Espionage is a first degree felony. It is not bailable," the judge said.

Liberia has accused them of filming in areas where they were not permitted to work, and of trying to damage Liberia's image and falsely link President Taylor to diamond smuggling and gun running.

An unidentified gunman shot to death a Protestant man at a house on Summer Street in a Loyalist area of north Belfast late last night, in what appeared to be the latest blow in a vicious feud between rival pro-British gangs.

Although no group claimed immediate responsibility, the fatal shooting happened only a few hundred yards from the spot where the outlawed Ulster Volunteer Force shot dead two Protestant militants on Monday, among them a prominent member of the rival Ulster Defense Association. The UDA had vowed to retaliate by killing UVF supporters in the area.

Despite the rising violence, Northern Ireland minister Peter Mandelson, insisted that a joint UDA-UVF cease-fire remained intact. Speaking before the latest shooting, Mandelson said he had no doubt that most commanders of the UDA and UVF did not want their feud to degenerate into a total breakdown of their 1994 truce, a pillar of Northern Ireland's shaky peace accord.

"It is possible for an organization to be on cease-fire but for individuals associated with it to be involved in unlawful activity," he said.

Mandelson also defended his decision on Tuesday to order the immediate arrest and reimprisonment of the most notorious militant, Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, who was seized at police gunpoint and delivered by helicopter back to prison. The brawny UDA commander was paroled early from prison last year under terms of the 1998 peace accord, but he had been accused of stoking up an increasingly violent turf war with UVF members, particularly in his Shankill Road power base.

Adair led a raucous UDA parade up the Shankill Road last weekend, inspiring gun attacks on a UVF-linked pub and several leading UVF members' homes. The UVF retaliated on Monday by fatally shooting two men, one of them an Adair subordinate, as they sat in a parked car on the nearby Crumlin Road.

Britain deployed police and troops into the Shankill district to deter an expected UDA counterstrike. Last night's shooting on a residential street just off the Crumlin Road happened not far from a joint police-army checkpoint. No arrests were reported in response.

Meanwhile, a Protestant man being questioned about involvement in Monday's lethal shootings was freed late Wednesday without charge. Detectives continued to question five others arrested on Monday during police raids on houses that contained eight guns and ammunition. Two were scheduled to appear in court today to face charges of illegal arms possession.

Had Mandelson ruled that the joint UDA-UVF truce had broken down, he could have ordered more than 150 convicted members of both groups to be returned to prison to continue serving their suspended sentences. Instead, he focused criticism on Adair, calling him the leading member of a small group of "gangsters and thugs who operate on the black side of Northern Ireland society."

He said Adair had been "given a chance to go straight," but had instead "whipped up the feud." The viability of the Good Friday peace accord depends in part on the maintainance of cease-fires by the Irish Republican Army, which draws support from the most militant Catholic areas, and Protestant-based gangs such as the UDA and UVF. Before calling their joint cease-fire, those two Protestant groups were responsible for slaying more than 800 Catholic civilians.

The cease-fire period has seen rivalry rise between the two groups, particularly once Adair returned home to the Shankill last year. Adair, 36, was convicted in 1994 of "directing terrorism," a previously unheard-of charge, after being taped by undercover police officers bragging about his pivotal role in terrorizing Belfast Catholics. He served just five years of his 16-year sentence.

Adair's close friend in the UDA-linked Ulster Democratic Party, John White, said Wednesday that lawyers had been hired to challenge Mandelson's reimprisonment order on grounds of lack of evidence.

Adair's wife, Gina, insisted her husband was being unfairly singled out. "There's loads of people out there inciting violence. Why just John?" she said. "Because of who he is."

But Mandelson said he didn't expect Adair to get back out any time soon. He said senior police and army commanders agreed Adair "poses too great a threat to public safety to be allowed to roam around and spread the sort of mayhem and terror that we have seen in recent days and weeks."

Reward to net Sarah's killer

A reward of more than £150,000 is now on offer to catch the killer of schoolgirl Sarah Payne, police said yesterday. Detectives appealed for photographs taken on July 1, the day of her abduction in West Sussex, on the beach where she played with her family.

ITV to fight news schedule ruling

ITV has won permission to appeal against an order by the independent television commission to reschedule its late evening bulletin. A judge will rule next month whether the network must move the 11pm Nightly News to an earlier slot.

GM crop safety margin widened

The company running this autumn's trials of GM rape seed has increased borders surrounding conventional crops to reassure the public over fears of cross-fertilisation. Aventis CropScience said GM crops at the 25 sites would be planted at least 100 metres from commercially grown rape, twice the minimum permitted distance.

UN investigates Briton's death

The United Nations has launched an investigation into the death of a British-born worker who was found dead in a hotel room in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Joseph Comerford, 42, was found dead on Friday in the eastern town of Kisangi.

Online wedding a British first

The advice could scarcely have come from a more surprising source. "If anyone tells you that GM is going to feed the world," Steve Smith, a director of the world's biggest biotechnology company, Novartis, insisted, "tell them that it is not... To feed the world takes political and financial will - it's not about production and distribution."

Mr Smith was voicing a truth which most of his colleagues in biotechnology companies have gone to great lengths to deny. On a planet wallowing in surfeit, people starve because they have neither the land on which to grow food for themselves nor the money with which to buy it. There is no question that, as the population increases, the world will have to grow more, but if this task is left to the rich and powerful - big farmers and big business - then, irrespective of how much is grown, people will become progressively hungrier. Only a redistribution of land and wealth can save the world from mass starvation.

But in one respect Mr Smith is wrong. It is, in part, about production. A series of remarkable experiments has shown that the growing techniques which his company and many others have sought to impose upon the world are, in contradiction to everything we have been brought up to believe, actually less productive than some of the methods developed by traditional farmers over the past 10,000 years.

Last week, Nature magazine reported the results of one of the biggest agricultural experiments ever conducted. A team of Chinese scientists had tested the key principle of modern rice-growing (planting a single, hi-tech variety across hundreds of hectares) against a much older technique (planting several breeds in one field). They found, to the astonishment of the farmers who had been drilled for years in the benefits of "monoculture", that reverting to the old method resulted in spectacular increases in yield. Rice blast - a devastating fungus which normally requires repeated applications of poison to control - decreased by 94%. The farmers planting a mixture of strains were able to stop applying their poisons altogether, while producing 18% more rice per acre than they were growing before.

Another paper, published in Nature two years ago, showed that yields of organic maize are identical to yields of maize grown with fertilisers and pesticides, while soil quality in the organic fields dramatically improves. In trials in Hertfordshire, wheat grown with manure has produced higher yields for the past 150 years than wheat grown with artificial nutrients.

Professor Jules Pretty of Essex University has shown how farmers in India, Kenya, Brazil, Guatemala and Honduras have doubled or tripled their yields by switching to organic or semi-organic techniques. A study in the US reveals that small farms growing a wide range of plants can produce 10 times as much money per acre as big farms growing single crops. Cuba, forced into organic farming by the economic blockade, has now adopted this as policy, having discovered that it improves both the productivity and the quality of its crops.

Hi-tech farming, by contrast, is sowing ever graver problems. This year, food production in Punjab and Haryana, the Indian states long celebrated as the great success stories of modern, intensive cultivation, has all but collapsed. The new crops the farmers there have been encouraged to grow demand far more water and nutrients than the old ones, with the result that, in many places, both the ground water and the soil have been exhausted.

We have, in other words, been deceived. Traditional farming has been stamped out all over the world not because it is less productive than monoculture, but because it is, in some respects, more productive. Organic cultivation has been characterised as an enemy of progress for the simple reason that it cannot be monopolised: it can be adopted by any farmer anywhere, without the help of multinational companies. Though it is more productive to grow several species or several varieties of crops in one field, the biotech companies must reduce diversity in order to make money, leaving farmers with no choice but to purchase their most profitable seeds. This is why they have spent the last 10 years buying up seed breeding institutes and lobbying governments to do what ours has done: banning the sale of any seed which has not been officially - and expensively - registered and approved.

All this requires an unrelenting propaganda war against the tried and tested techniques of traditional farming, as the big companies and their scientists dismiss them as unproductive, unsophisticated and unsafe. The truth, so effectively suppressed that it is now almost impossible to believe, is that organic farming is the key to feeding the world.

Muslim rebels fighting to create a hardline Islamic state in central Asia were yesterday closing in on the Uzbek capital, Tashkent, after battling their way across three countries.

Up to 200 gunmen, who crossed into the country at the weekend, fought their way to within 60 miles of the capital, killing several Uzbek soldiers.

Last night they were hiding in Bostanlyk, a holiday resort north-east of Tashkent. Health spas in the town have been emptied of holidaymakers and the roads to the capital are under heavy guard.

Government artillery and troops were being moved into the resort.

"The area has been surrounded, but we have so far failed to locate the gunmen," an Uzbek government source said yesterday.

The rebels are believed to be members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which opposes the secular government of the Uzbek president, Islam Karimov, and wants to create an Islamic state in the rugged mountains of Central Asia.

They are thought to have crossed from their bases in Tajikistan through mountain passes into Kyrgyzstan, where they fought fierce battles with government troops in the past fortnight, leaving at least 18 soldiers and 40 rebels dead.

Last week the Kyrgyz president, Askar Akayev, said 50 gunmen were engaged in heavy fighting with government troops after entering the country from Tajikistan, where he said more fighters were massing.

"Another group of over 150 is right by the border," he said. "We know that around 800 well-armed bandits are operating from the Tajik border region."

Leaders of the central Asian states accuse Afghanistan's fundamentalist Islamic Taliban regime of training the men, who include well-armed snipers, among them Arabs, Pakistanis, Chechens, Russians, Ukrainians, Kyrgyz, Uzbeks and Tajiks.

The Taliban, who have imposed a brutally strict interpretation of Islamic law across most of Afghanistan, says they only give the rebels moral support.

Russia keeps several thousand troops in a border security force along the Tajik-Afghan border to counter what it sees as a threat from terrorism and religious extremism, spreading north into the former Soviet states of central Asia.

Russian border guards killed six gunmen who were trying to cross from Afghanistan late on Tuesday. Many of those crossing are smuggling drugs. Last week, Russian guards shot dead 10 smugglers on the border and recovered 118kgs of heroin.

The battle for control of internet incubator Enterprise Asia turned nasty yesterday when the directors of the company circulated a note to shareholders which painted a damning picture of their predator's track record.

Construction entrepreneur Stephen Dean, a 21% shareholder in Enterprise through his building firm Artisan, is demanding a shake-up at the company and wants to join the board. However, he is described in the report by Enterprise as having "a history of disregard for independent shareholders' rights".

Enterprise said allegations that it had used private investigators to compile the report were "rubbish" but admitted it had hired a business analyst to trawl over Mr Dean's career.

Mr Dean was refusing to comment last night. However a spokesman said that he will be issuing a statement shortly. He believes Enterprise should use its cash pile to invest in established UK net ventures rather than firms in the Far East.

Enterprise's directors allege that Mr Dean has been a director of a company that bore his name and went into receivership, and that Mr Dean was "obliged in June 1997 to admit to a number of breaches of law" while a director of Dean Corporation. They document other instances where they allege he did not have the interest of independent shareholders at heart.

An extraordinary general meeting will be held on September 20 when shareholders will be asked to vote against Mr Dean's proposal to oust two members of the board and replace them with three representatives (including himself) from Artisan. A statement from the board yesterday said: "The effect of these resolutions would be to give control of your company to a minority shareholder, Artisan, which is not prepared to make any offer for your shares."

Earlier in the year Mr Dean had suggested to the board of Enterprise Asia that it merge with VoyagerIT.com, a company of which he is chairman and a shareholder. The board rejected the plan as unnecessary to the company's future but invited him to put "serious" business suggestions.

Phill Brown, a director of Enterprise Asia, said last night: "The only conclusion we can draw from Mr Dean's refusal to take up any of our offers to demonstrate a genuine interest in the strategic direction of the company is that he wants to grab the cash and run."

For the last year we've been making a documentary called Movie Virgins, following Leon Herbert and Alex Jovy (pictured) trying to get their first feature films off the ground. Leon's is a no-budget domestic drama, Alex's is a clubland thriller with a £3m budget. We've followed them writing scripts, raising money (or not), casting (or getting turned down), getting nowhere, getting somewhere, then the momentous, almost unbelievable first day on set... the shoots, the escalating costs, the tantrums and the traumas of seeing if what was in the script worked in the cutting room.

Movie Virgins was allocated a prime-time 9pm slot by Channel 4, and we wanted, above all, to make it accessible. In the cutting room we were ourselves trying to weave hours of documentary footage into a four-part story. It was a challenge in the first place to start filming unknowns with incomplete scripts and no budget, just hoping to get them from script to screen. As Leon and Alex were trying to complete their features and meet deadlines, our own transmission date was looming. So where to end the documentary? Their stories were still going on. Then a fax arrived from Channel 4. The Sunday movie was being moved to the earlier 9pm slot, with Movie Virgins to follow. And with a different start time each week, which makes it hard to build an audience. We protested - to no avail.

Still, Movie Virgins had good reviews ("I'm hooked", "compelling as a car crash", "enthralling") and doubled its audience from week one. Strangers approached in the street - to commiserate with Alex about being snubbed by Jude Law in Cannes, and even to offer Leon tenners to help him finish his film. People were saying they'd stay up to watch what happened next instead of videoing. There was a buzz. Then last Friday we summarily received a call from the Channel 4 schedulers. Movie Virgins, we were told, was being ejected from the schedules to make room for a repeat of an update on Nasty Nick's own eviction...
