Live television, as anyone from Noel Edmonds to Chris Evans to Nasty Nick will tell you, is a risky game at the best of times. With the added pressure of lines to remember, cues to miss, and the constraints of just a week in which to put it all together, tomorrow night's episode of ALT-TV, Play In A Week, is packed with drama before the actors even open their mouths.

For the final instalment of the experimental ALT-TV series, writer Nigel Forde has been set the task of writing, casting and directing a half-hour play in a week - the first drama to air live on British television in a long time.

On Monday he scoured the papers for a newsworthy story to base his script on. Tuesday, the cast was booked and thrown into rehearsals. Yesterday a composer was found to write the soundtrack, while Norman Stone, director of the TV version of Shadowlands, prepared to direct the cast and crew through what has the potential, at least, to be one of the more interesting half hours in this summer's TV schedules.

Of course, in the days before edit suites and videotape existed, this was how all TV drama was made, filming what were essentially live theatre productions straight to camera. In the mid-60s, Dennis Potter cut his cathode teeth writing a bold series of live Wednesday Plays like Where The Buffalo Roam or The Confidence Course, packed with British actors like Yootha Joyce and Stanley Baxter. Some of these are lost gems which weren't even taped on transmission as the film stock was considered too expensive to be used for creating a huge library of material - a broadcasting strategy that seems bizarre in our era of endless chances to see stuff we didn't want to watch first time round.

In the States, shows such as 1956's Playhouse 90 gave directors like John Frankenheimer an hour and a half of live television every week in which to adapt works from heavy weights Ernest Hemingway, George Bernard Shaw and William Faulkner, as well as nurturing young writers like The Twilight Zone's Rod Serling. The series is still regarded as one of the highpoints of the golden age of American television, which may explain the small but growing trend towards live TV drama in recent years.

ER was the first to pull off the live show stunt, with the opening episode of the 1997 season featuring a documentary crew shooting the bloodthirsty chaos of Chicago's most famous hospital for a day. The cameramen jumped out of the way of bodies on gurneys, captured a few intimate moments between Carol and Doug, and generally contrived ways to film the high-paced drama in a continuous stream. Because of the five-hour time difference between the east and west coasts, the cast even had to repeat the performance after a two-hour break.

It's an experience that the show's then star George Clooney obviously enjoyed, as he decided to repeat the endeavour in April this year by throwing his Hollywood clout behind a remake of his "favourite film".

Originally broadcast live in 1964, Fail Safe is a cold-war nuclear paranoia thriller about an airforce bomber that has inadvertently been given the order to nuke Russia. Hardly a burning contemporary issue, but given the bonus thrill of live transmission, one that commanded a respectable enough audience. Clooney roped in his ER pal Noah Wyle alongside Richard Dreyfuss, Harvey Keitel, Don Cheadle and James Cromwell, with Stephen Frears directing 18 cameras across two soundstages. Fail Safe was such an extended exercise in repeating the past, they even went so far as to shoot it in black and white and broadcast it with a letterboxed picture.

Both ER and Fail Safe were met with enthusiastic reviews, full of praise for the energy and vitality of the live experience - something of a novelty in today's culture of endless retakes and technical perfection. Both were also pulled off without any glaring mistakes from the cast, something which may have disappointed the rubbernecking section of the audience. It's undeniable that a major part of the thrill of live drama is waiting for someone to fluff their lines, especially in a format like television, where the audience is far enough removed from the cast to be able to revel in, rather than cringe at an actor's amnesia.

This live aesthetic has spread to film, with Lars von Trier's Dogme 95 school of intimate wonky-cam directors offering a hardcore modern interpretation of cinema verité alongside the real-time experimentation of Mike Figgis's current Timecode - itself essentially a play that was filmed live, albeit from four different perspectives.

It's an old idea, and one that used to be the only possibility available to TV directors. But the very fact that a show is being broadcast live still has the power to add an element of risk that's hard to match. And, if tomorrow night's Play In A Week is a success, it's a safe bet that it won't be the last time you see live and direct drama on TV.

ALT-TV: Play In A Week, tomorrow, 7.30pm, Channel 4.

After seeing Nick Moran on Movie Virgins a couple of weeks back acting like a spoilt Brit-flick brat on a Cannes rooftop terrace with Jude Law, the prospect of watching his nobody-ness in Hollywood seemed unmissable, his just desserts. But, as the excellent Starstruck (C4) continued its exploration of fame and fortune with a programme focusing on the price of celebrity and success, poor Nick's plight made him positively sympathetic.

A koi carp in a swimming pool here, in LA he was a minnow in an ocean, just another British actor reading for bit parts in duff action movies. He may have got a free suit from Prada for the American premiere of Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels, but he was small fry nonetheless. And he knew it. Like All Bran, humbling experiences may not taste great but they are good for you.

With a supporting "cast" including Anjelica Huston, Adrian Lester and Billy Bob Thornton all giving insiders' critiques of the business we call show, Starstruck once again probed the inner workings of celebrity like a master surgeon. While all had interesting points to make - Rufus Sewell's anger at his cooperation with his own humiliation at auditions was particularly memorable - it was to Sienna Guilroy that Starstruck belonged. Nick Moran's girlfriend, she spoke candidly of how awful it is going out with someone everyone wants to know while you slowly turn invisible, three steps behind them.

Incidentally, if that room in which Fay Ripley is interviewed for Starstruck is actually in her house - and not some swanky hotel suite - wouldn't it be great to be her flatmate? With all that space and nice coloured cushions, you could cartwheel from the dining table to the front windows at least three times without fear of smashing any ornaments.

Unlike Lowri Turner's, which - if it is her house from which she presents The Lipstick Years (BBC2) - is jam-packed full of hideous ornaments culled from a jumble sale at Lady Tavistock's country pile.

This week, concentrating on housewives, there were moments of The Lipstick Years which were surely cues for country and western songs. There was Shirley Conran's "No One's Going To Strangle You If The Mantelpiece Is Dusty", Nigella Lawson's "I'm No Scrubber But I Bake A Mean Biscuit", and my personal favourite, "Feed The Baby, Load The Twin-Tub And Pass the Mogadon". (Actually, there is a country song - by Mary Chapin Carpenter - called "He Thinks He'll Keep Here", which would have made a very good theme tune for this episode).

The drum beats to which the righteous march, the synthesised trumpet noises suggesting heroic institutions, the urgent bass line hammering home an evangelical cause: the music for Crimewatch would prompt even Mad Dog McGough and Razors Robinson to phone in and say "Keep up the good work." For fitting its programme like a comfy cardigan, Crimewatch comes second only to Casualty. And, just as Nick Ross saying "Don't have nightmares. Do sleep well" has absolutely no periaptic properties but is still oddly comforting, so the Crimewatch music irrationally stirs one's civic conscience. A call to arms, no less.

These are the dog days of August however (the dogs having eaten the salad days) and there is no crime, so Crimewatch UK: Solved (BBC1) was dedicated to crimes "you, the public" helped solve. The happiest endings you could expect from some thoroughly nasty crimes (child abuse, murder, armed robbery and football hooliganism), it was part self-congratulatory and part public relations exercise for the police. This reconstruction-fest was full of cheeky, charming, non-swearing, non-racist, non-sexist policemen who must listen to the theme tune from Crimewatch on their personal stereos - after a chorus of Zip A Dee Do Dah - on their way to work. Knowing that the public probably wouldn't accept stations full of happy clappy coppers, there were - in a unique concession to reality - a couple of gruff types. They were Scottish, naturally.

Whatever this bunch of officers were investigating, their gravitas was tempered by humour and their determination by concern for their victims. Naturally, one doesn't expect The Cops-esque drug-taking and corruption during Crimewatch, but this was The Bill on Prozac. Join the police - everyone's nice.

It is almost like a cliché from a Mills & Boon romance, but there is no escaping the reality that it was the passionflower cascading down the front of his handsome house beside the river Thames that changed the life of Leo Abse so completely and so unexpectedly. The old man was on his doorstep above the public towpath in Chiswick one sunny afternoon a couple of years ago when a beautiful young woman stopped to admire and ask about the flower.

He is the wealthy retired solicitor and former Labour MP who was once the author of much private member's legislation on homosexual, marriage and family law reform. More latterly, since leaving the House of Commons in 1987, he has written books about the psychology of politics. He is 83 years old.

She is Ania Czeputkowska, a former electrician from Gdansk in Poland, who came to Britain without a word of English, acquired a diploma in general arts and design, took a degree and got a first while working as a cleaning lady, won a bursary to the Royal College of Arts to study printed and textile design and has now just been awarded her master's. She has sold designs for fabric production in New York and to one of Britain's best-known wallpaper firms. She is 33 years old, and three weeks ago in the rather unglamorous surroundings of Hounslow register office she married Leo Abse. They have returned from honeymoon in a castle at Sintra in Portugal; they are tanned and happy, and exude a delighted contentment in each other. It is an unusual and enchanting story.

Leo Abse was widowed five years ago. Marjorie, his wife of more than 40 years and the mother of his two grown children, died and left him desolate. He cut a sorry, bereft figure. "Although I was holding on, it was tough," he says. "It was an arid period. You behave stoically, but not happily." He has two brothers: the poet Danny and an elder brother, Wilfred, a distinguished psychoanalyst in the United States who rather shocked him by suggesting that he should snap out of himself and find a young woman. "I had thought, 'I'm going to die a widower and this is the way of life I have to endure until my death.' " Wilfred changed his thinking, and shortly afterwards Ania strolled into his life.

In some ways the attraction was a classic one. Her father died of cancer when she was just one year old. Her mother, an administrator with the Polish national transport system, never remarried and raised Ania and her elder brother alone. As a child, Anya was a brilliant mathematician but an undiagnosed dyslexic until the age of 18. She found her Polish examinations, in subjects except maths, incredibly difficult. She fled them one year to come to England with a friend and spent two happy months picking strawberries near Colchester, living in a tent.

Although she went home and worked as a precision mechanic, repairing irons and hair dryers, then as a technical demonstrator in the physics department at Gdansk University, she wanted to return to Britain. She supplemented her income at home by working as a florist, or selling vegetables, or being a parking warden, and eventually came to study art and learn English in London. She had one or two boyfriends, but they were not serious or didn't work out. Leo, she says, was the first man to make her feel like a woman.

She was fascinated by him when they met. She knew nothing of British politics and little of psychology. He invited her and her girlfriend for tea to talk about passionflowers, he asked them round for a meal and then again. Her girlfriend teased her that he was "after her", and she became suspicious. He took her to the Savile Club, bought her wine, sent her perfume and lent her books, and she became more uneasy. She turned down further invitations, sent the perfume back and returned the books with a note which read: "I don't think I am the woman you are looking for."

Three weeks later she telephoned him again, and this time allowed a relationship to develop. After a while, exhausted from cycling between her job, her flat, her college and his house, she decided to move in. He suited her. She wanted to look after him. "I let go of all the suspicion and I started listening to him," she says. "We have made an effort. We somehow understand each other and there is a friendship that has been built up in the last year - to know each other you have got to live with each other, to see each other every day."

"She is an all-or-nothing woman," says Leo, admiringly. He remembers the moment when he realised they were going to have to get married. "Here was this woman who is enormously creative, who has an ability to battle through and to stand on her own feet, who is formidable and who has won her way to the most prestigious art college in the country and yet who has time to notice that my socks had holes in because my toenails needed cutting. It was when she was cutting my toenails that I realised I would have to marry Ania."

They laugh delightedly at how prosaic this is. Neither of them is embarrassed about their love. Leo says that he is far too old to care what anybody else thinks and Ania is a woman who knows her own mind.

Their homecoming has been a little marred, perhaps inevitably, by the excessive interest of the tabloid press. Leo Abse, with his fascination with psychoanalysis, understands this better than Ania, who has been tidying up the garden since they got back to Chiswick, filling nine bags with weeds and clippings rather than going out to face the intrusive lenses that have appeared from time to time on the doorstep. "They really want a picture of her in a bikini," says Leo, chuckling with undisguised delight and mischief at his capacity to stir up controversy yet again.

She, however, was a little upset and greatly astonished by the fact that in their absence on holiday the press pursued their friends and relatives across the continent. "What disturbs them is the intergenerational relationship," says Leo. "It can stir up fears. It is too near incest and the great taboo, of course, which has to be maintained to have an acceptable society is against incest. Freud said ..." and he is off and away on his favourite subject. Ania listens with a commendable serenity for a while, until she starts to disagree. "Hold on, Leo," she says. "Hold on," she repeats when he doesn't hear her, for he is quite deaf. Then, if he still persists, she will put a restraining hand on his arm or raise her hand to him across the room in order to interrupt his flow and make a point.

They disagree, for example, about babies. "If it happens, it happens," he says. It is improbable in any case that they will start a family, he says, but Ania will be able to cope, just as her mother did; he means when he is not around to see any children of hers grow to adulthood. Ania says that she is more interested in her career, in sorting her priorities with the exciting possibilities that she has ahead. She is less certain about raising children on her own, however capable she is.

In the meantime, there are other, more immediate hurdles: Leo's children need to get used to the idea of his changed circumstances; her mother has needed reassurance. And she wants to be able to emerge from her front door without being photographed. They chose to talk to the Guardian because they don't want their relationship sensationalised. They have nothing to hide and just wish to be free to continue walking hand in hand down life's towpath.

It was like a history lesson as we passed the 12th-century abbey at Fearn, the name derives from the Gaelic Fearnn meaning alder tree. Then, nearer the east coast, the remains of Cadboll Castle that was probably built around the same time although it could have been earlier. Cadboll means "dwelling of the wildcats" although I doubt very much whether there any true wildcats in the area these days.

The very impressive Glenmorangie House, now a hotel, adjacent to the castle was started in the 17th century but the reason for our visit was to see a much smaller structure in the grounds and built comparatively more recently. The doocot is a rectangular lectern type with a single sloping roof and the date on the lintel of the lower door indicated 1805 with the initials GR. This type of doocot superseded the older beehive type in the 16th and 17th century and they are unusual in that they are only found in Scotland and France.

It was good to see doos flying in and out. The presence of two doors, one above the other, may indicate that the bottom part was used for another purpose such as keeping poultry or pigs. A much smaller hole in another wall was probably for taking out dung which was modified to make a form of gunpowder. The two walls on either side of the sloping roof project upwards above the slates to protect the doo entrance holes. Three of the walls had a double rat course which are projecting ridges to stop rats climbing up to the entrance holes.

On the top of the doocot were five decorative round stone balls known as finials but the most striking feature was a three feet high metal silhouette shaped like a country gentleman in colourful breeches, boots and black hat and carrying a gun. One source said the figure was a weathervane whilst another said it was a scarecrow but my guess is that it was to scare off the birds of prey.

Considering its age and apart from a few dislodged slates the doocot was in good condition and it was exciting to add it to our own inventory of doocots in the Highlands.

Anthony Ogbise, 81, is among the few who have remained in Odi after the destruction. The Nigerian army came in the early hours, razing house after house, but carefully bypassing the banks and government offices, until they got to his door.

"They dragged me out and a captain said 'go and wash him', which meant they would kill me next to the river and dump me in the water.

"Somebody hit my arms and head with the butt of a gun. Another kicked me in the stomach. But they didn't kill me. They dragged me to their headquarters and beat me more.

"They used kerosene to burn the houses. I'm 81 years old. I'm not rich. I can't build a new house."

There is not much left of Odi. Almost all its several thousand houses were burned by the soldiers. Hundreds of people were killed and buried in shallow graves beside the road. All but a few of the people fled.

The destruction did not occur at the hands of one of Nigeria's repressive military dictatorships. It happened just nine months ago under the elected civilian government of Olusegun Obasanjo.

The government blamed the army. The army accused militant Ijaw youths of provoking the attack by murdering a group of policemen in the town. The youths said the government was to blame, because it failed to fulfil its promise of relief for the Niger delta.

The region's misery is well documented. The 2m barrels of oil pumped from the delta each day provides more than 90% of Nigeria's foreign income. The delta communities have little to show for it beyond contamination, repression, and an ever more restless younger generation which has found violence, hostage-taking and extortion in place of jobs.

Changes for the worse

Today the burnt-out houses stand as a monument to the failed hope that democratic rule would rescue the delta. Its blighted communities looked to the new government to ensure that the region benefited from the riches it gives up. But a bill to set up a development commission to return some of the oil profits to the delta is stuck in the national assembly, a victim of the endless feuding between MPs and President Obasanjo.

"Things haven't improved," said Oronto Douglas, one of the more militant of the Ijaw youth leaders and head of the Pan Niger Delta Resistance Movement.

"In some instances they've actually got worse. There is a general belief, especially in the west, that the coming to power of Obasanjo has changed things for the better. I would say he is practising dictatorial democracy.

"It is democracy designed by dictators and run by an ex-dictator for the benefit of the cronies and hangers on."

Compounding the misery is the phenomenon of oil pipeline explosions. A month ago 312 villagers scooping fuel from a burst pipeline deep in the bush at Viri-Court were killed when two wheelbarrows carrying off the plundered oil collided and provided the spark for the blast, which extended almost a mile along the pipe. Trees as far as five miles away were scorched.

An organised racket

The survivors, many of them children with third-degree burns over much of their bodies, can be found in local hospitals. Many others with serious injuries refused to go to hospital, despite the authorities' assurance that they would not be arrested for stealing fuel.

A week later 18 died in a similar blast two miles away. A week after that it was 40 near Sapele. In all, more than 2,000 people have been killed in pipeline explosions in the past two years.

The oil companies accuse villagers of breaching the pipes, either to steal the fuel or to claim compensation for the resulting pollution. But in one recent explosion it was clear that the pipe was so old that it had fallen apart.

There is also evidence of a well-organised racket involving the police, army and employees of the state oil company, the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. The NNPC concedes as much by saying that it is not easy to breach a pipeline.

"Our engineers have told us that vandalisation of oil pipelines takes a scientific process which ordinary villagers can't engage in," its spokesman, Ndu Ughamadu, said. "There must be well-placed people that have links with this pipeline vandalisation. Where they have located a pipeline they will perforate holes and quietly they will lay pipeline up to one kilometre where they siphon the fuel at will."

The oil is pumped into lorries, sometimes guarded by soldiers, and sold on the black market or driven across the border to places where fuel prices are much higher. When the tankers leave, villagers move in at great risk.

The NNPC's managing director, Jackson Gaius-Obaseki, said the damage extended far beyond those caught in the explosion.

"The fear and mourning are not only for the dead but for millions of Nigerians living in communities around the vandalised sites, who would be inhaling hydrocarbon vapour and would either suffer lung cancer or begin to die gradually."

Eleven communities hit by the recent pipeline explosions, including Viri-Court, are seeking £34m in compensation "We want to let the world know that the fire affected lives and property within a 20-kilometre [12-mile] radius, creating a devastating effect that will last for the next 1,000 years in addition to leaving an everlasting group of widows, widowers and orphans," their spokesman said.

"Our communities suffered the environmental degradation of all streams and rivers. Our main sources of drinking water were severely polluted and all flora and fauna destroyed."

The government has sent paramilitaries to guard the pipelines, but environmental watchdogs accuse them of connivance in the looting, and of killing and raping villagers. The fuel thieves can be just as violent: a month ago a soldier guarding a pipeline near Warri was beheaded by men he tried to stop stealing fuel.

The explosions are a blow to the oil companies' attempts to mend relations with the delta communities. With vast new oil finds about to be exploited, they are keen to end the occupations of oil installations and hostage-taking by youths demanding "compensation" and jobs.

Earlier this month 165 workers, including 20 foreigners, on two Shell drilling rigs were taken hostage. There have been hundreds of similar if smaller cases in recent years. Usually the hostage-takers are paid to go away.

But, for the first time, the companies are also facing effective legal challenges. Shell Nigeria, a consortium which includes Elf, Agip and the NNPC, is appealing against a high court award of 4bn naira (£24m) compensation for a 30 year-old oil spill which has still not been cleaned up.

It says it has long paid compensation for spills, which is true. But the companies know that the money did not go to clean up pollution or benefit the affected communities, but straight into the pockets of the soldiers and politicians.

That suited the army and the companies, which bought their way out of moral and legal responsibility. The companies say times have changed, and so they have. But the people of the delta have yet to be convinced that they will benefit.

Are you one of those nauseating people who love every second they spend at work? Do you see a slack Thursday afternoon as a wonderful opportunity to do some advance planning for the next few weeks? If so, this article is not for you. To the rest of you: welcome, my brothers and sisters.

Being bored at work is one of the most depressing activities you can endure. Yes, flicking rubber bands out of the window at doddery octogenarians can be diverting, but only at a high cost to your karma and the NHS's hip replacement units. Thankfully, the internet has started to come up with some high-quality diversions for the office idler.

These can be completed while online, or printed out for a much more satisfying pen-on-paper experience. If you're a real hardcore crossword freak, run along to www.wordcross.net, which manages a cryptic crossword league (strange but true) with weekly prizes.

Compared to discussing last night's Animal Hospital in the office kitchen, doing a puzzle or two can actually boost morale and freshen your mind, giving you more creativity and energy when you do tackle some work. If you don't have the energy to interact with your computer, there are sites where you can sit back, relax and let the internet take the strain. The Onion has the best spoof news around, despite hailing from the irony-desert that is the United States. Updated weekly, it is just about the most hilarious 10 minutes you can spend on the web.

Yes, we've certainly come a long way since the days of hangman and battleships, played covertly with the person on the desk opposite. There are few people around nowadays who can genuinely enjoy the experience of visiting a car showroom. With British cars branded as the most expensive in Europe, potential buyers are continually worried about being ripped off and are frequently driven away by the hard sell techniques of aggressive sales people.

Against this background, it is hardly surprising that increasing numbers of people are turning to the web to help them buy a car. Quick and easier access to cheaper prices, more transparent information and the ability to browse anonymously are the chief reasons why the internet is starting to put pressure on the traditional practices of the UK car industry.

Most big car manufacturers and dealers have a presence online but with a few exceptions - including Vauxhall and Peugeot - many of them are not selling cars on the web. Instead they are still opting to channel sales through their physical dealerships.

But now that relationship is being challenged. In a move designed to exploit consumer dissatisfaction with the industry's practices, new web-based car retailers are selling cheap cars imported from Europe, and slashing the prices on UK-sourced cars. The new sites can generate savings because they are not saddled with the overheads of large dealer networks.

Richard Branson's latest venture, Virgin Cars, imports and sources cars from select UK dealers. The company promises headline-grabbing savings of between 10% and 30% on normal retail prices and, since the end of May, has sold about 1,000 cars online. Cranking up the hype in the usual way, the company is offering test drives, financing and servicing arrangements. There are also plans to promote the service through Virgin's chain of Megastores.

Ian Lancaster, the chief executive of Virgin Cars, says, "Traditional dealers tend to muddy the transactions.

"If you buy a car from us and your neighbour buys the same one, when you're talking in the pub you'll always discover the price is the same."

He adds that consumers appreciate the fact the business is not tied to one particular car manufacturer.

But Virgin faces competition from the likes of Direct Line, which has recently launched a car retail service called Jamjar.com. The company sells imports and has gone into partnership with Dixon Motors to source UK vehicles. It is claiming savings of up to 30%, benefits from Direct Line's established call centre and can also spread word of its new service among Direct Line's millions of motor insurance customers.

What is most impressive about the new car websites is their ability to provide tailored information far more effectively and efficiently than a traditional on-the-floor salesperson. When you search online for a car on Jamjar's site you can specify your maximum price, number of seats and size of engine, or select a gimmicky lifestyle option. Then you can choose cars on the basis of how you want to look; swanky and fashionable or more modest and sensible.

When you have bought your car, Jamjar emails out a digital photo of the vehicle; and if you are doing a part exchange the company will value your car online based on your appraisal. But be warned: if your description does not match the car accurately when Jamjar collects it, the deal will be off.

In a bid to build long-term relationships with its car customers, Jamjar also offers an online shop where you can buy anything from spark plugs and clutches to audio books to keep the kids happy on a long journey.

Other high-profile entrants to this emerging online market include Inchcape-owned Autobytel UK and Oneswoop. Autobytel UK was launched in April and, rather than selling cars direct to the customer, supplies information and then refers web-based customers to its accredited "real world" dealers. The company says it has sold more than 6,000 vehicles since its launch.

So is this how we will all buy our cars in the future? Forrester Research predicts that in the UK the web will be primarily used for browsing and gathering purchasing information, rather than for actual transactions. That means, although the number of online car purchases will be small, the web will be influencing about 500,000 car purchase decisions a year by 2003. That is a market worth about £5.7 billion.

In the US, where the car market is governed by different practices, the internet is tipped to have a much bigger direct impact. Jupiter Communications forecasts that online-direct and online- influenced car sales will be worth $128 billion by 2004.

Peter McCullough, managing director of Autotrader Interactive, acknowledges that UK consumers still have strong reservations about buying cars online. Cars, he observes, are a different proposition to CDs and books.

"Consumers are confused about what is going on," he says. " They are afraid to buy from dealers and they do not fully understand the online services."

Nevertheless interest in what the web has to offer is growing. Autotrader, like other car magazines, runs private and dealer ads on its web pages and sees more than three million vehicle searches a month on its site.

With more of the car buying population going online, there have been reports of major portals planning to join the race to capture the emerging market. Amazon.co.uk has reportedly approached dealers including Dagenham Motors about the possibility of retailing cars. Meanwhile, earlier this year, the company bought car-related domain names including newcars amazon.com and usedcars amazon.com , although a spokesman for Amazon will only say: "We are not ruling anything out, but there are no plans at the moment."

The arrival of new online car retailers has not been without controversy. Some UK manufacturers have accused new car websites of quoting indicative prices rather than firm ones. Many also question whether the internet can genuinely revolutionise car buying and argue that only quality car products will shake up the market.

There are also lingering doubts about the ability of a distribution channel like the internet to handle transactions for complex cars. In those cases, industry insiders believe face-to-face consultations are essential.

Forrester analyst Caroline Sceats believes websites which depend on imported car sales will not survive in the long run.

"I think the models with the longevity are the models which source cars from dealers or manufacturers. The reason for that is because the opportunity for the import model is based around price disparity and we are seeing the prices of cars in the UK coming down."

Car manufacturers, used to handing bulk sales, may struggle to adjust to direct one-to-one sales over the web. However, many are beginning to realise that the net presents a unique opportunity to reach out to consumers.

In a new move to develop further opportunities to publicise its brand, General Motors, known in this country as Vauxhall, has announced it is investing in a new UK teenage site called Curve.com.

And on the fashionable business-to-business front, Daimler-Chrysler, Ford and General Motors have formed a business-to-business market called Covisint www.covisint.com which could improve the speed of their component supply networks, generate savings, and make them more responsive to customer requests.

Legislation is also likely to have a decisive influence on the future shape of the market. In 2002, it is expected that European legislation called the block exemption will be repealed, and this could allow dealers who are currently tied to one manufacturer to sell a greater choice of brands.

That means they may promote themselves more aggressively, and raises the possibility of car retailers being able to buy directly from manufacturers.

But at the end of the day, the real winners, whether offline or online, are likely to be those car retailers who can successfully cement relationships with their customers which last for the entire lifecycle of a car, from buying right through to all the after sales services. They will be the ones to beat.

Voice portals, reputedly the next boom industry in the world of the web, are the technophobe's dream come true. Imagine: you can get up-to-the-minute information from the internet just by picking up your phone anywhere, any time. No more fiddling with a temperamental mouse. No more twiddling your thumbs as your server cranks into gear. You would not even have to know how to use a computer.

Several companies have launched voice portals in the US in the past two months, including, BeVocal, Quack, TellMe and Audiopoint, and the trend is due to hit Britain in about a year. They use speech recognition technology to get information from the web and "speak" it to you down your phone line. All you do is dial a freephone number and ask for what you want.

You cannot just surf the web, but you can find out cinema times, check your stock portfolio or listen to the latest headline news. You can call up travel information before you leave the office, or get driving directions when you are lost. You can choose and book a restaurant table, and hear film or book reviews, or your horoscope. All straight off the web. All without touching a computer.

Experts are predicting massive growth: the Kelsey Group, a market analyst firm, estimates that in five years, 18 million consumers will be using some kind of speech recognition portal.

Voice portals have been possible because of advances in two crucial technologies: speech recognition software (from companies such as Lucent, Nuance and Speechworks) can now understand natural speech in a wide range of accents and diction without having to be trained to a specific voice. And new standards such as VoiceXML are beginning to make it as easy to write voice services as HTML did to write web pages.

With VoiceXML, your voice takes the place of a mouse and your spoken command is like a click. You cannot call up conventional web pages, but you can access information that has been specially composed for the phone: sound clips, music or text spoken by the computer (in a Stephen Hawking voice).

The bad news is that the big bucks will come from advertising. The Kelsey Group predicts that advertising revenues on voice portals will reach $17 billion in 2005. So does this mean that when you ring to check whether there's a traffic jam on your route home, you will have to endure 10 minutes of Pamper's ads? I am based in the US, so decided to get a taste of what Britain will be in for.

I started with Tellme, the most hyped 'V-commerce' firm and reputedly the best. Using the service is so simple, even the most tech-terrified could do it. Instructions - in a real human voice, rather than anything scary and automated - are clear and repeated often frequently. It understood my British accent without a glitch and in less than two minutes I had narrowed my restaurant search to 10 Vietnamese eateries in the area I wanted. I heard a couple of reviews, with gradings for service, decor and food, and when I had picked one, Tellme connected me directly to it, so I could book there and then. The ads were unobtrusive (though this could change as the service expands) and it only asked me, grovelling apologetically, to repeat myself once.

Others - I tried four more - were also generally easy, though, as you would expect during a roll-out period, the information available varied. Audiopoint, which allows you to customise its service, gave quick, and surprisingly comprehensive, information on current travel problems in my area. BeVocal was the exception: after it had asked me four times at the start for my phone number ("I did not understand you"), I hung up in irritation.

Simplicity is, in fact, the selling point of voice portals, perhaps because people have less patience on the phone than at their terminals: "I wanted to build something that my mom would use," says Michael McCue, Tellme's chief executive. The everyday consumer who is fed up with technology angst and the complexity that has come about from the rise of the internet can still use the net."

With 1.7 billion telephones in the world, McCue's potential market is certainly capacious. This is why most companies are trying to give themselves a particular spin: Tellme's speciality is dining suggestions. With TelSurf you can read and send email over the phone. And BeVocal claims to be the last word in road directions.

But it is not clear whether the technology will work as well with millions of users as it does with a few thousand. Also, it won't be free if you're on a mobile phone - probably when you will need a voice portal the most. It is no wonder that British mobile operators like Orange, Vodafone and One2One are rumoured to be developing voice portals of their own.

But the race for British custom is on. Tellme expects to launch in Britain by the end of 2001 and Audiopoint, which launched in the US last week, is "talking to people in Europe". So next time you're grappling with the yellow pages, watching your PC crash, take comfort: voice portals are on their way.

Where this differs from its competitors is its MDP (mouse-driven power) system. This involves a rotating ring below the athlete with a fixed marker on its inner circumference. The object is to keep to the mouse button depressed while the green section of the disc passes beneath the marker, and to release it when it gets to red. This seems simple enough, and makes a half-decent stab at modelling athletic action.

In practice, though, it is a strain to have to focus on a spinning disc, especially in the longer events. And when you are concentrating on a space just below the athlete's feet, you tend to miss out on other things - like where the no-throw line is, or what your athlete looks like. Back in the good old days, when games came on tapes and keyboards dressed in rubber, all manner of movie licences were hastily ported on to the dominant genres of the day.

Robocop was a side scrolling platform game, while Indiana Jones offered similar thrills. Batman? Well, rest assured, there were plenty of ledges to reach.

In short, movie licences quickly became known as a shortcut to an unimaginative, lazy and pointless game.

Unfortunately, in the 21st century things have got little better. With the exception of Goldeneye, film-licensed games are still struggling to reach mediocrity. Remember Phantom Menace?

However, the just released X-Men movie, with its freakish set of characters, seemed to offer the basis for a cracking game. So, what do we get? Certainly not a stylish adventure epic.

X-Men is, in fact, a fighting game - and a bog standard one at that. Graphics? Fine. Sound? Adequate. Originality? Snore, er pardon?

X-Men shamelessly filches Street Fighter's feel and ridiculous special moves before adding some Tekken character design.

And, if you have always suspected that beat-'em-up games are hollow exercises in button-bashing, then look here for confirmation. Extensive blindfold testing has revealed that random finger gymnastics are often as successful as a more studied approach.

Anyhow, with rewards including movie clips and comic photos, you would have to be a real fan to want to practise this one.

Despite the inclusion of 10 X-Men characters, comically pummelling each other in front of some authentic movie backdrops, this is uninspiring fare. Shamelessly derivative, and with a pungent whiff of cash-in, X-Men is yet another film-licensed disappointment. (GH)

Wham, BAM - the bubble bursts

But like the later, fancier versions of Tetris, Bust-A-Move 4 has lost much of the simplicity that was one of its attractions. Adding more puzzles, and bubbles with different behaviours, has made it a bit more challenging and a lot more confusing.

In the graphics department more turns out to be less. This is one of the few games that does not seem to benefit from the Dreamcast's superior graphics and sound. In fact, BAM4 takes the saccharine Japanese graphics style to a peak of excess. It is so cute it makes Super Mario Brothers look like gritty realism.

The aim of the game is the same. You shoot coloured bubbles at a descending network of existing coloured bubbles, and they stick together. When three or more bubbles of the same colour are stuck to one another, they burst, and fall down the screen. But not only can you remove three or more bubbles this way, you can also remove any bubbles that depended on them for support. This is the tricky bit, and the way to score huge bonuses, in what is always a race against time.

BAM4 is a very playable game, and a welcome addition to the Dreamcast line-up, especially at the price. But the original PlayStation version was simpler and just as satisfying. (JS)

Brain box
Nasa has developed a technology that it claims will enable video gamers to enjoy better health. Nasa researchers say that, using biofeedback, people can be trained to change their brainwave activity or other physiological functions while playing popular off-the-shelf video games.

The system involves attaching sensors to the player's head and body and feeding the output through a signal-processing unit to a joystick or other controller.

"As the player's brainwaves come closer to an optimal, stress-free pattern, the joystick becomes easier to control. This encourages the player to produce these patterns or signals to succeed at the game."

The idea was developed using flight simulators and has been tested at the Eastern Virginia Medical School (EVMS) in Norfolk. Nasa says, "several companies have applied for a licence to produce training systems for the general public."

What does OpenTV do? OpenTV is the worldwide leader in interactive television, introducing viewers to a new TV experience through their remote control.

Why do you think viewers want to interact with their TV? Isn't one of the attractions of the TV that it is a passive experience? TV is all about leisure, information, ease of use, impulse reaction and emotion. Interactivity builds on this by giving people the opportunity to respond to the programmes they watch, get information when they want it or buy products when they see them.

We hear a lot about convergence - where various entertainment and computer functions are going to come together in a single box. So is the TV turning into a personal computer, or is it the other way around? TV is for entertainment, whereas the PC is focused on work and processing, so your expectations and use of the TV and PC are different. You may see email on interactive TV but you won't see an Excel spreadsheet. Interactive TV needs to be easier to use, graphics rich and more reliable - people don't want to have to re-boot their televisions! Also, the TV is a true mass market product, so it needs to be kept at a low price.

OpenTV operates across the world - what differences are there between countries, other than language, which you have to take account of? There are major differences in viewing habits and the level of complexity that TV viewers want. We have to make sure that our applications can be customised. Nonetheless they will work in all environments, whether they are delivered by satellite, cable or terrestrial networks.

Are you trying to sell interactive TV as a replacement for the web and internet, or as a supplement? These are two co-existing marketplaces. Many people will have internet access and interactive TV but will use them for different things. Interactive TV will also reach people who don't have computers. This is why many companies are looking to have a presence on interactive TV and the internet, adapting the range of products they sell, services and information accordingly.

How do you use technology in your work? At work I use computers, email, the internet and my mobile phone to make sure I am available no matter where I am. At home I use interactive TV to do things like checking my bank account and getting a weather forecast.
